Alex I have tracked down a couple off dependencies that might make renaming the page inadvisable.

We have a feed running (TimelaseCameras) once an hour, which collects images from Site-Eye Live and names the pages to which these images are saved.

While it would be relatively simple to edit this feed, the second dependency is the Stamen timelapse overlay. If we change the name of the page in the feed, it will create a new page, which would would be likely to interfere with Stamen's ability to capture the data for the new camera.

A simpler solution might be to just change the copy on the page below the image, or--as you have already done--take the image off line for now.

It would make more sense to look at this post-launch, I think.

Hi Danny

 

It's fine in that I can remove the timelapse.

 

In terms of renaming, the feed doesn't need renaming, but the page does.
As all we have done is moved the location of the camera from Stadium to
MPC. It is still the same feed, but a different location so it just
needs to be renamed.


So in other words, don't need to touch the feed name, just the page
name...


Alex

In comparing the 'external-paths' file sent from Stamen with the current site, I notice that the old paths of renamed page have not been removed from their database and are showing up on the map. These will be cleared out with the new site, but presumably will accumulate again over time.

I am not sure if this occurs just with renamed pages or any page that is removed from the site.

An example:
"http://www.london2012.com/blog/2009/06/25/our-screens-are-live-at-glasonbury.php" renamed to "http://www.london2012.com/blog/2009/06/25/our-screens-are-live-at-glastonbury.php"
Another example: /news/2006/04/lemley-chairs-first-oda-board-meeting.php. Looks like this one was moved rather than renamed.
